text: Down a mountain trail Loretta Webb, 13, rides a mule, whi is pulling a little wooden sled. On the sled is her broth Herman, 10, with a glob of white salve on his forehead.

Pitch black except for the miners' headlamps. Ted Webb, 4 drills a hand auger into the coal face. Powder is tapped -- "Fire in the hole!" -- and explosion. Miners crawl bac through the dust and shovel coal into a mule cart. A fore man shouts "Payday today, let's go!"" The miners shovel f
Loretta and Herman move down the ridge toward the mine.
A dozen miners come out of the mine, including Ted. His trousers are torn at the knees, which bleed slightly.
Loretta and Herman are waiting for Ted as he comes down t road.
Hi, Daddy -- boy, look at your knees, Daddy. Why ain't you a- wearin’ your kneepads?

Aw, Loretty, that ol' shaft is so low, if you wear your kneepads, you skin your back. Don't wear ‘em, you skin your knees, (grins) Wear ‘em tomorrow, I reckon. Give my back a turn. They continue on down the road. cs

location: ROAD THROUGH VAN LEAR COAL CAMP

text: A muddy red jeep flies over the ruts toward the company s driven by a young soldier with a plump, sexy girl beside The jeep careens into the storefront drive causing severa miners to leap out of the way, laughing and cussing.
Ted looks at the salve on Herman's forehead. The little b jaws are clenched tightly shut.
What you so sulled up about, Herman? What's that stuff on your head?
Herman's scared to open his mouth. We was playin' up by Prod Bottom and a ol' green snake bit him right on the head. Daddv, ain't it true that if a green snake bites you, you laugh yourself to death?
That's what I always heard.
That thing bit Herman two hours ago. He's been clampin' his jaws shut ever since so he won't start laughin'. Ted looks at Herman and smiles to himself. Loretta sidles to Herman and says quietly:
Be careful, Herman. One little smile's liable to start it. And you'd just never stop. Herman glowers furiously at her. They are approaching ---
The young soldier ~- Doolittle Lynn, 19 -- holds forth co from the jeep as the girl, Lizzie, looks on. The others l as a jar of moonshine makes the rounds.
ps 5
Boys, there ain't no place this thing can't take me -- no gully she can't jump, no creek she can't ford, no hill she can't climb.
By God, I know one thing you can't climb -- that heap of red-dog past the mine up yonder.
Hell, buddy, I can climb that damn mess backwards.

(going up steps with the kids) You boys watch your language with these children here. Doolittle salutes apologetically; Lizzie giggles. Ted glo and continues on to the pay window which is part of the s He gets in line. Loretta hangs back, listening.
Who wants to bet me I can't climb that red-dog?
Backwards, you say?

Hell, yeah, backwards! (to Loretta) ‘Scuse me, little girl. Backwards, right up to the top -- I got fifty dollars says I can do it! Who'll bet me? The others boisterously get up the money. Doolittle grins winks at Loretta. Flustered, she runs to Ted who is at th pay window getting paid in scrip.

Come on now. Let's get in the store and give the company their money back. Frowning in Doolittle's direction, Ted goes into the stor Loretta watches interestedly as Doo loudly covers all bet (ad lib). Then she goes in the store.
Loretta watches the action outside through the front wind Ted is at the counter with the Storekeeper.
Who's that soldier boy out yonder struttin' like a banty rooster?

That's ol' man Red Lynn's boy, Doolittle. Come back from the army just as wild as a hearthern. That Germany war's just ruint these mountains -- boys come back here don't want to do nothin' but cut shines and act wild.

He'll calm down some when they slap a coal shovel in his hand. That Sears~Roebuck I ordered come in yet? Storekeeper nods and moves off to the rear. Loretta watch as out front Doolittle's jeep races off toward the mine, others scrambling after on foot, her eyes glowing with su excitement. Ted notes this.

Loretty -- get you a can of vy-annies for you and Herman. Her face lights up; she instantly forgets Doo and the jee gets a can of Vienna sausage from the shelf. The Storekee returns with a large brown mail-order package.
(eagerly) What's that, Daddy? Ted grins and says nothing.

At the foot of the smoldering heap of waste Doo revs his as Lizzie and the others watch. A few of them are buying of moonshine from a man in a clump of trees nearby -- Lee Rainey, with a mule loaded down with bags of shine. Seein Ted, Loretta, and Herman approaching -- the mule-sled loa with groceries and the large package -- he waves and shou
Hey, Cousin Ted! Come here and get in on this bet -- it’s a sure thing.
ps

LEE (Cont'd) O1' Doolittle never get up there without rollin' over and killin' hisself! Ted comes up, nods. Lee grins at Loretta. She grins back is more interested in Doo and the jeep. Doo roars backwards up the red-dog pile, gets a little wa slips, slides, spins wildly -- showering burning ash on t spectators who scatter laughing. Then, just as he's about tip over, the tires catch and the jeep seems to spurt to top of the mound. The crowd cheers as Doo poses triumphan
(whooping) Lord-a-mercy -- that sumbuck Doolittle don't know what quit means, does he?
(dryly) He sure went to a lot of trouble to get on top of a heap of trash. But Loretta is watching with bright, excited eyes....

As Ted and the kids climb toward the cabin more kids burs from the house and run toward them -- Junior, 16; Jack, 1 Peggy Sue, 6; Donald Ray, 9. At the door is Clara, 35, ho Betty Ruth, 11 months. The kids converge on the package a Loretta races to a wooden well and begins drawing a bucke water.

You young'uns take that stuff in- side -~ and don't open that package til I get there. They rush inside with supplies. Loretta empties the water into a battered wash pan and Ted washes the coal dust off face and hands. Loretta waits with a towel.
The kids look on eagerly as Ted opens the package. Clara "Mommie" -- looks on from the kitchen door, holding the b
Pps 10 11
The package is opened -- new shoes. Kids gasp happily and clamour for them.
Y'all kids hush -- you ain't a- touchin' them new shoes ‘till you washed them dirty feet. The kids all slam out of the house toward the well. Ted s Loretta.
Wait a minute, Loretty -- try this on first. He takes a blue dress with little flowers out of the pack Loretta gasps happily -- races into the bedroom to try it
Them others gonna be wantin' to know why she's a-gettin' treated so special.
Loretty's thirteen, Clary. She orta have her one dress that ain't made out of no flour sack.

She undresses to her homemade underclothes. On the walls this room she shares with her parents, are plastered news and magazine pages -- with sepia photos of Loretta Young, Gregory Peck, Clark Gable, Scarlett O'Hara, visible. The kids are heard pounding back inside as she pulls on the n dress, thrilled and excited.
putting on their new shoes, walking around looking at the feet, etc. Loretta enters in her new dress -- a size too
Well, looky here. Right pretty, ain't it, Mommie?
I reckon she'll grow into it fast enough.
jm il 12 13 14
CONTINUED ll
How come she's a-gettin' a new dress?
Loretty's a woman, Jack. Women got to have pretty things to wear.
Aw, she ain't no woman. She just a dad-burn kid. Herman laughs -- the other kids join in.
You're a-laughin', Herman. Reckon that's true about the green snake after all. Horrified, Herman remembers his snakebite. Loretta laughs and runs into the bedroom.
looks at herself in a tarnished mirror, primping in her t large dress, pulling the loose material as tightly across fledgling bosom as she can.
Lee Rainey is working his moonshine still. Hearing a nois the bushes, he snatches up a rifle.
(from bushes) Lee Rainey! It's Doolittle Lynn.
Come on in here, Doo. I'se just about to blast you one. (gets a jar) Here, take you a sip. Rest your- self. ‘Member when you used to work for me, Doo? Sellin'’ my goods down't the mines?
I ‘member you used to pay me a nickle ever jug I sold.
jm 14
Pause.
How'd you like to come back and work for me again?
Not for no nickel a jug.
I'm talkin' about real money, Doo. Business is good, see. I'm sellin’ more whiskey than I can make.
Yeah, I heard you been stealin' whiskey from them boys over in Greasy Creek.
Aw, just when I run shy of my own. They become aware of singing in the distance -- a girl's voice, young, clear, singing a mournful ballad: "I the Pines." Both men freeze and listen.

That's my little cousin, Loretty Webb. She sits down there on her daddy's porch, a-singin' her little sister to sleep. I be up here workin' and hear her and I think, Lord, let me die if angels sing that sweet... : (beat) I'm fixin' to make me another run on Greasy Creek. You got that jeep, you know how to use a gun, and you need you a job. I'11 go fifty- fifty with you.
Sounds like a good way to get killed to me.
Doo, o1l' Uncle Nat Ramey used to say, if you born in the mountains, you got three choices: coal mine, moon- shine, or move it on down the line.
(gets up) I ain't sayin' no. But I gotta study on it first. He gives back the jar and goes into the woods.  jm 15 16
EXT. RIDGESIDE - SUNSET is Doo looks down into the holler at Loretta in the porch sw with the baby, singing. He stands listening, thoughtfully to the sad ballad....

Loretta tunes an old battery-powered Philco radio: Ernest Tubb's "“Walkin' the Floor Over You." At the table Clara upturns her coffee cup into the saucer and "reads" the gr as Loretta watches. The baby cries in a homemade cradle. comes in holding his head in pain; a bloody handkerchief his nose.
Don't run the batteries down on that radio, Loretty -- can't afford no new ones.
You got one of your bad headaches, Daddy?
I'll mix you up some medicine ---
It don't do no good, nothin' does. Just this family weakness, have to suffer it.
Take the baby out and rock her, Loretty.
(getting baby) What do you see in the grounds, Mommie?
Woman cryin'. A man cryin', too.
Who are they? What are they cryin' about?
Clary, I swear it's bad enough you bein’ an ol' squaw medicine woman without makin' Loretty one, too.
She's Indian much as me. We can see things other folks can't. Take the baby on out, Loretty. {looks back at grounds) Some bad times comin'....
Don't need no fortune teller to know that.
Loretta in the porch swing, sings to the baby: "I come to the garden alone, etc." Her clear voice soars up the ridge in the still morning air....

Lee Rainey on the run, pulling a mule loaded with stolen whiskey. His pistol in his hand, he looks behind him desperately. Then, hearing Loretta's voice, he stops, smiles. A twig snapping spins him around in terror ---
The sun shining down through the trees...shadowy figures among them...one of them raises a rifle....

Loretta, singing, hears a shot ~- then a volley of shots. the ridge a flock of crows caw raucously. Loretta peers u the ridgeside. Silence. Emptiness. She stands on the porc clutching the baby, looking up, curious and frightened.
The face is caked with blood and dirt, the body riddled w
kt 20

bulletholes. An old woman wails piteously nearby, pacing and down. The body is carried into the yard by several me including Doolittle. They lay the body on the-grass as Te Red Lynn, relatives and neighbors look on.
He wanted me to go with him. I should've gone, I might could of helped him.... Others say nothing; stare at the body.
Loretta cowering in Clara's arms, staring at the body. He eyes meet Doolittle's briefly; then Clara leads her insid
Doolittle looks up and sees Loretta; their eyes meet brie Then Clara leads her back inside.
Maybe we orta get our guns and go visit Greasy Creek.
(shakes his head) It wasn't nothin' but Lee's craziness caused this. Hadn't a'been this, it'd been another thing.
(to Doolittle) Good thing you wasn't still a-workin' for him, son. ‘You'd be layin' there aside him. (beat) ‘Course if you'd been workin' for
kt 21
RED LYNN (Cont'd) Lee at least you'd a-been workin' somewheres.” af Red cackles; the others frown. Doo looks thoughtfully at the corpse. ‘ - .
Explosion: Smoke clears. A miner crawls through it: It is Doolittle. He begins shovelling coal into the mule cart. looks trapped and frustrated.

Wintertime; a light coat of snow on the little school. In it's brightly decorated for Christmas. A fiddle and banjo guitar play "Cumberland Gap." Several horses are tied out Doo drives up in his jeep, parks, goes in.

A cakewalk in progress (like musical chairs), with Lorett playing. Doo enters and spots her right away; she is very pretty in her new dress -- which now fits nicely. Doo decides he's going to meet her. He ambles near a table wi several pies on it, with name cards. One is Loretta's. Nearby, a Churchwoman is talking distraughtly to the Teac a sour-faced chain-smoking man.
Preacher Banks was supposed to auction off these pies for the girls, but he's sick and I can't do it ---
Well, I sure ain't got time to auction no pies! Besides, if them girls wants a boy to eat a
TEACHER (Cont'd) pie with ‘em, they'll do it auction or not! He stalks off. Churchwoman looks desperate.
Hey, lady? I'11 auction off your pies for you.
(great relief) You will? The Lord'll bless you for this, son.
(glancing at Loretta) Maybe he will. Never can tell.
At the pie table.

Six bits, six bits, who'll gimme a dollar -- dollar once, dollar twice -- sold to the man for a dollar. He's enjoying being center of attention. A boy collects a pie and a girl, and Doo picks up Loretta's pie. She watch nearby, blushing.
Got one more left, a chocolate pie here, belong to Loretta Webb -- who's gonna bid first? A large boy named Flop Murphy. looks bashfully at Loretta
I bid two bits.
Two bits? Man, that's a insult. Who'll start it off for a dollar?
pl 24
(waits; no one bids) I guess I get it then.
I bid a dollar.
You the auctioneer -- you ain't supposed to bid.
Dollar once, dollar twice ---
(hastily) Hey -- dollar'n a dime!
Three dcllars.
That ain't fair -- he's cheatin'! As Doo says "once, twice," FLOP ° Three and a dime!
Three seventy-five.
(in agony) Three seventy...seven.
Five dollars. Flop flops heavily into a chair, stunned.

Once, twice, sold to Mr. Doolittle Lynn for five dollars. Crowd applauds; Doo claims the pie and Loretta -- slightl dazed, blushing furiously -- and gces to a corner where h cuts a piece with a pocket knife.
(rattling nervously) Ain't nobody ever paid five dollars for a pie before, I bet. Mommie said,

LORETTA (Cont'd) girl, ain't nobody gonna buy a pie off you cause everybody knows you can't cook no better 'n a day-old heifer. Wait'll I tell her, she just gonna die! Five dollars! She watches expectantly as Doo takes a large mouthful. As chews, his eyes bug out, he chokes, he gets to his feet a looks around desperately. Loretta watches in alarm as he frantically throws open a window, thrusts his head out an spews out the pie. He then grabs a pitcher of lemonade an washes his mouth out.
You made a lotta chocolate pies before?
(nervously) Not too many...'cept for that one.
How much salt does your recipt call for?
Shoot, you don't use no salt in a chocolate pie -- just sugar, and (beat) Oh, no....
Guess you got ‘em mixed up. Under- standable, they both bein' white and all.
(moaning) Oh, no...! You gotta get your five dollars back.
I don’t want no five dollars back. I just want you. (she looks alarmed) I mean, I want to take you home.
Doo leads Loretta to his jeep.
pl 25
No use walkin' when you can ride. Get in.
(looks at jeep nervously) I ain't gettin’ in that thing.
You ain't never even rode in a car before, have you? I be damn.
(embarrassed) That thing ain't no car anyway -- looks like somethin' come from Mars.
What do you know about Mars? Bet you ain't never been past the foot of the holler. Come on, get in ---
I said I ain't gettin' in that thing and I ain't! You just walk it home if vou think so much of it!
(slightly taken back) Whoo. You pies ain't the only thing salty about you, is they? Let's walk then.
They walk, Doo holding a pine-torch. Below them the mine brightly lit as the night shift works.

I had my eye on you a long time. I told myself, sooner or later me and that little gal's gonna get together. . Loretta, thrilled, gropes desperately for a response, but nothing comes out. Doo goes on.
You're different from the rest of ‘em around here. Special. Like me. The kind of person that's gotta have more out of life.
om” ps
.--More what...?
More'n what Butcher Holler's got to offer. (indicates mine) More'n this.
(trying to flirt) I saw you, too. In that little ol' soldier suit. I thought, he looks just like a little toy soldier.

(angry) Listen here -- I joined the army to feed my Mamma and nine brothers and sisters. I went ashore at D~Day plus four and I'se in combat til the day the war ended. I wasn’t no little toy soldier, lady. Frightened by this outburst, Loretta draws back. Doo glow at her a moment, then grins. They walk on.
They walk slowly toward the lights of the cabin.

The army showed me it's a whole big world out yonder -- and I ain't about to spend my life buried in no damn coal mine. Ain't a damn bit of future in it. That's what I'm interested in -- the future. What's your plans for the future?
Ain't got none that I know of. (beat) You sure cuss a lot, don't you?
Yeah. Cuss, drink, and chase after wild women. Suddenly he pulls her toward him; she's alarmed.
What're you doin' --
Fixin' to kiss you goodnight. You ever been kissed before? She hasn't; quickly decides she likes it. They do it agai They break, Doo grins, hands her the torch, she awkwardly for the cabin.
I'll bring my jeep up here and take you for a ride.
(breathless) You'll never get that thing up the holler.

There ain't nothin' I can't do, once I put my mind to it. She smiles uncertainly, rushes into the cabin. Pleased wi himself, Doo turns jauntily and smacks into a fence post, careens downhill through bush and stones, splashes into a rushy creek where he lies moaning but happy.

Clara, making lye soap; Loretta dreamily adding wood to t fire beneath the rendering kettle. Ted is plowing with th mule in the garden, A shout from down the holler’.(from Junior): “Stranger comin' up!" followed by a shout from Herman a little closer; “Stranger comin'!" Everybody stop working and looks toward the trail: A faint sound, an eng straining uphill...Loretta recognized it's Doo's jeep, he face lights up...The rest of the family looks puzzled, a frightened, as the sound gets louder and closer...Suddenl Herman and Junior burst through the foliage into the yard ling and pointing behind them where --- Doolittle's jeep seems to leap out of the foliage and int yard. He stops proudly, his face bruised and cut from las night's accident.
Told you I could make it up here. Now you're gonna take a ride with me!
Loretta excitedly clambers in -- and Doo roars off instan before Ted and Clara can make a move or speak. Ted is fur
Loretta hangs on, frightened and excited, as Doo speeds d the bumpy mountain trail. She looks at his battered face.
What happened -- was you in a fight?
Yeah -- me and this fence post got into it.

What? Doo just laughs. They speed up a steep mountain road, pas slow-moving coal trucks; through the drab streets of Van now decorated for Christmas, with people staring. Loretta gets more and more excited and breathless until:
screeches to a halt. Loretta looks down at the drop, exci dizzy. Doo grabs her and kisses her.
I can't breathe...I feel like I'm a-gonna faint....
That's how you're supposed to feel when you're in love.
It is...? They kiss again; she throws her arms around his passionat
sits grimly, a willow switch in his hand, watching the do Clara and the other children are all there, waiting...Lor comes in. Stops guiltily, seeing them:
mw 30
Where you been, Loretty...?
Doolittle...took me ridin'....

You just run off. Didn't ask or nothin'.... He begins switching her around the legs; she whimpers and tries to hop out of the way; the other children scatter. has tears in his eyes, hating what he's doing. Finished, breaks the switch and goes into his bedroom. Loretta is d up in a corner, rubbing her legs, sobbing.
(to other children) Y'all get to bed -- right now. They quickly vanish. Clara examines the welts on Loretta' legs.
(continuing} Don't you know he'd rather cut his arm off than to whip you? What did you mean, runnin' off like that with that wild boy?
(sobbing) I love him, Mommie.

(angrily) You don't do no such thing. I'11 mix you some salve for your legs. {starts for kitchen) You stay away from Doolittle, Lynn -- or I'll give you worse what your Daddy did. Clara exits. Loretta sniffles miserably, but a faint look defiance is in her eyes.
The family sits listening as Clara reads the Nativity sto
from the Bible (Luke 2ff). Loretta hears Doo's jeep pull outside; then his footsteps on the porch and knock on the door. She watches Ted nervously as he answers.
Evenin' Mr. Webb. Loretty here?
We're havin' our family Christmas, Doolittle.
Yessir. I just brought this present for Loretta, and if she'll step out here. I'll just give it to her and go. Ted hesitates, then nods. Loretta runs eagerly onto the porch as Clara resumes reading.
They kiss. Doo gives her a package -- she opens it -~ it contains a large doll baby.
(angrily) What are you givin’ me this for? You think I'm just a little kid or somethin'?
That's just for now. '
What do you mean?
I mean by next Christmas, me and you'll have us a real little doll. She looks confused.
Me and you is gonna be married pretty soon.
He kisses her, grins, jumps off the porch and runs back t jeep. Loretta stands incredulous, holding the doll...Insi Clara continues reading the Bible.
leads the male and sled; Loretta follows with a carbide l

A vein of coal in the mountainside which families have tunnelled into over the years for their private coal. Lor holds the lamp while Ted chops the coal. Everything is bl except their two faces, close together.
(after a moment) Loretty, you know I don't like to boss you, don't you? But I got to, now.
Daddy ---
Just lemme talk. I don't want you to see Doolittle no more. You promise me that.
I can't, Daddy.
(chopping at the coal) You're just a little girl. He's a growed-up man -- a wild one.
I love him, Daddy -- he's a-wantin' me to marry him.
(shocked) You ain't even fourteen yet. Y'all ain't even knowed each other a month ---
I know, but I just love him.
Lord, Lord, don't do this, Loretty -- don't throw all your young years away. I worked hard all my life, got very little to show for it except you. You're my pride, girl, my shinin' pride ---
(tearfully) I just can't help it, Daddy --- Ted can't speak; chops at coal face, jaws clenched shut.
assembled. Loretta aloof from the others, sad and depress Ted tunes the Philco to a familiar voice:

From the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville, Tennessee, this is the Solemn O1' Judge speakin' and this is the Grand Ole Opry -- let ‘er rip, boys! Bill Monroe and his Bluegrass Boys cut loose with "Blue M of Kentucky." Ted claps his hands, trying to cheer Lorett up.

Get up and do your squaw dance, Mommie ~- see if you can't get a smile out of ol’ sourpuss here --- Clara hesitates, then throws down her sewing and does an energetic hoedown. The others clap and shout. Ted watches Loretta but she remains sadly aloof. Suddenly, the door o and Doolittle steps in, awkwardly. Everything stops.

I knocked, but reckon y'all couldn't hear me. Loretta runs to him, instantly happy. Ted looks at her; s _ thing seems to drain out of him. He clicks off the radi goes out onto the porch. Clara goes into the kitchen.
Looks like I broke up the party.
(takes his hand) Don't matter. Come here and sit down --- The other kids begin to giggle.
mw o~ 35 ao 36
Y'all get outta here or I'm gonna smack the tar outta ever one of you! They scatter in various rooms, sniggering and smirking.
(as they sit on the sofa) Look here at this. He pulls out a wad of money.
My gosh -~ where'd you get all that?
Paycheck. Been savin’ 'em. You know what tomorrow is? Our anni- versary. Loretta spots Herman making a face around the corner.
Herman, I'm gonna kill you! She leaps up and smacks him hard, chasing him around the until he can escape into the kitchen. Then she returns to the sofa,
What was you a-sayin', Doo?
I said tomorrow is our anniversary -- we met a month ago tomorrow. I think it'd be a good day for us to get married. Specially since I just got all this money.
(stunned) You'll...you'll have to ask Daddy.... Doo nods and goes out on the porch.
He is hunkered on the steps, smoking a cigarette. Doo com up.
Uh, Mr. Webb...? I'm fixin' to marry Loretty. If it's all right with you. Tomorrow.
CONTINUED 3€
{also stunned; long pause) Go ask Clary. INT. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT’ ~ LORETTA 37 watches as Doo comes back in and crosses to the kitchen.
sits reading the coffee grounds in her saucer.
Miz Webb, me and Loretty want to get married, tomorrow.
(pause) Go ask Ted.
She sees Doo cross back out to the front porch. Her broth and sisters continue tormenting her as she waits in suspe After a moment Doo comes back and starts for the kitchen
Doolittle, what are you doin?
Aw, Ted says ask Clara and Clara says ask Ted and ---
Come here. Just sit down and wait till they go to bed, then you can catch 'em together. Else, they'll keep you runnin' back and forth all night. Doo sits with a sigh.
They are half asleep on the couch when Ted and Clara fina start getting ready for bed. When they are both under the covers, Doo comes to the doorway.

Mister-Miz Webb, I know how you feel. Everything's happened real fast. And I know she's young, and I know how much y'all love her. But the deal is, I love her, too -- as much you do. I seen a lot of the world and I growed up pretty fast, but the minute I seen Loretta, I knew she was all I'd want in this life. And I swear to you -- I'll bust my back workin’ to make her happy.
Reckon you're set on it, no matter what we say.
I don't wanna go against y'all, Miz Webb, but...yeah. We're set on it.
You promise me two things, boy. Don't you never hit her. And don't you take her off far from home.
I promise you that. He goes. Through the door he can be seen kissing Loretta night. Then she comes in to get ready for bed.

Mommie, Daddy -- I'm so happy I don't think I'm gonna be able to sleep! (silence) Are y'all still awake? An odd, muffled sound from their bed; both are crying sof Loretta stands in the dark, listening.

A Judge performs the ceremony in the cold empty courtroom Angie Lynn, Doo's mother is there, a few others, but no C or Ted. As the ceremony goes on, Loretta looks around for them. Ted comes in at last, doesn't sit, leans on the wal the rear.
Who gives this woman to be wed? Loretta looks around at Ted. After a long pause, he nods,
{to Doo) Do you have the ring?
I ain't got no ring, Judge. Judge pronounces them man and wife. They kiss. Loretta lo up just in time to see Ted duck out the door....
Doo's jeep with a canvas cover pulls up in front of one o plain wood cabins. He and Loretta jump out -- it's freezi cold -- and dash for the door.
He goes to a radiator and turns it on. Loretta in a teddy bear coat stands shivering. Doo flips his suitcase.

She'll warm up in a minute. Hey -- I got a present for you from Mama. He tosses her a nightgown, then goes into the bathroom. S ering with fear and cold, she sits on the radiator, clutc the nightgown. Hearing the toilet flush, she looks mortif In a moment Doo comes out in his undershirt and army skiv She quickly averts her eyes.
(indicating bathroom) Go on and get ready for bed, baby. She nods numbly and goes in as Doo turns back the bed.
The lights are out, Doo waits in bed, she steps cautiousl of the bathroom, in the nightgown, and gets into bed. Doo embraces her, then:
{laughs, says tenderly) Loretta? You ain't supposed to put your nightgown on over your clothes.
I'm freezin', Doo.
(patiently) Go on back in the bathroom and take off everything but your gown. Go on, now. Embarrassed, she goes.
She clicks on the light and we see how completely scared is, She dutifully removes all clothing from beneath her g
She comes and gets into bed again. Doo moves....
Doo -- hey, don't, that ---

If we're really gonna do this thing, we gotta go see ‘em -- in person -- make sure they play that record! I already talked to your mama -- she said she'd take care of the kids: But we gotta move now -- understand? She says nothing; turns away.

All right. JI ain't gonna push you into nothin'. It's your choice. If you don't want it, we'll just go back to what we was doin‘, that's all.... She slowly looks at him as he steers the tractor down the
(softly) I want it, Doo....
Can't hear you.
I want it -- I want to be a singer! I want it real bad, Doo?! Doo says nothing; just nods and steers the bulldozer....

Doo and Loretta getting into the car; the kids crying and clinging to them. They pull away; the kids all clinging t Clara now. Loretta looks back waving as long as she can.. until the car disappears down the trail away from Butcher Holler.  ps 86 87 88
The car speeds along; the Radio is being tuned, stations skipping by, static, etc., until:

«..your voice of country music in the tri-state area. And now here's that big number one hit by Miss Patsy Cline, 'Walkin' After Midnight.' Loretta leans in and turns it up. Doo checks the Cash Box list of stations and DJ's taped to his sun visor.
All right. Station WCBL. DJ's named Bobby Day. Keep your eyes open for the transmitter.
The what? Doo gives her a look. ANGLE - STATION TRANSMITTER -— DAY 87 looming over the landscape, a small station at the foot.
drives the car into the parking lot. Loretta's in the bac in panties and bra hurriedly trying to pull on her dress the sewed-on sequins and a pair of white boots.
Doggone it, Doo, wait -- people can look in here and see me!
Hurry up, then -- we're there.
I don't know what to do once we get in there -- what am I supposed to say?
Don't even think about it -- just talk. He parks; she frantically tries to pull her boots on.  ps 89

Small operation; nobody there except the DJ, Bobby Day, e a sandwich at his microphone while a record plays and an engineer in a control booth. He is startled to see Lorett in her dress and Doo in his white hat stroll into the stu
Uh -- hey -- sorry, folks -- no visitors in the studio ---
(gamely) Uh, hi, Bobby! Uh, my name is Loretta Lynn. And. Uh. I sent you a picture and my brand new record on the Zero label. And.
(hastily) What? Look, folks, no kiddin', you can't be here while I'm doin' a show -- okay? Engineer signals “stand by" -- record is ending.
(sweating) It's a song I wrote myself called ‘Honky Tonk Girl'. I got the idea from ---

(thinking fast) Yeah, right -- I got it and played it. Just sort of laid there -- now thanks for comin' in y'all -- (on the air; signals Doo and Loretta to be quiet) You're listenin' to tri-state country with your Deejay, Bobby Day right here til six o'clock, neighbors -~ and now, here's a word from our good friends down at Hutchen's Hot Pig. A recorded commercial begins. During the above Loretta ha spotted her record -- unwrapped, in a stack of others. Di traught, she waves it at Bobby.
You played it, huh? You ain't even took it outta the wrapper!
(as commercial continues) Look, you know how many do-it- yourself records I get ever day? If I played them all I wouldn't have time to play anything else ---
But why'd you lie to us? Why'd you say people didn't like us? Doolittle worked so hard to get us that record and --- She cries loudly.
(frantically) Hey, shut her up, willya? I'm goin' back on the air ---
(nonchalantly) Ain't nothin’ I can do, pardner. Once she gets wound up.... "On the Air" sign comes on; only one thing for Bobby to d
(shielding mike from her sobs) Folks, we got a special treat for you here today -- a young lady who I predict is gonna go all the way --~ Loretta stops crying and looks at him.

Tell the friends and neighbors all about yourself, darlin’. He thrusts the mike in her face; she panics, goes totally Looks around desperately for Doo -- just in time to see h bolting out the front door. She looks back at Bobby and t to speak.
bursts out the front door, dives into the car and turns o radio, nervously waiting for it to fade in; finally ---
(on radio, sound- ing very at home) -- and then I sung it for Doolittle -- that's my husband -- but every- one else calls him Mooney on account of he used to sell moonshine back in Butcher Holler ---
(laughing) Where?
can't believe it; she sounds like a pro.

Butcher Holler -- that's where me and Doo is from back in Kentucky -- anyway I wrote this song and Doo said that's about as good a song as I ever heard, good as Patsy Cline, and I said, aw, ain't nobody good as Patsy.
Well, folks, let's give it a listen -~- brand new, on the Zero label, Miss Lorene Lynn singing ‘Honky Tonk Girl' ---
(as record starts) Loretta. Loretta Lynn. Not Lorene. In the car, Doo laughs out loud.
Both laugh, happy -- Loretta peeling off baloney slices, sandwiches for them both.
You sure got over bein' bashful fast.
I done what you said -- just opened my mouth and out it come. I couldn*t stop -- and I didn't have no more notion of what I was gonna Say than a rabbit!
kt o~ 92
oo
Well, you just keep on bein' a rabbit, then.
Where's the next one -- want me to watch out for that transmitter?
Yeah -- watch out for that trans— mitter. They speed on down the highway.

Lonely transmitters against the sky; the car speeding dow two-lane country highways; highline poles; the call-lette signs of small country radio stations; and close shots of the car radio as the dial skips across it. We hear snatch of widely-ranging music: Pat Boone "Love Letters in the S Ray Charles, "What'd I Say?", Kingston Trio "Tom Dooley", Peter, Paul and Mary "Blowin' in the Wind", Buddy Holly " Fade Away" and finally, loud and clear, Loretta's record.

location: COUNTRY HIGHWAY AND SMALL ROADSIDE GROCERY

text: The car pulls up to the pumps in front of the store. They get out and go inside.

A radio is playing behind the counter: Lefty Frizell's "Please Release Me." Doo points to a roll of baloney in the freezer and a fat, old woman starts slicing it. Loret wanders around looking at a display of candy and toys.
Doo, can we send the kids some suckers or somethin'?
We ain't got a cent to spare, baby. Loretta nods, resigned, watches as the old woman wraps th baloney in paper.
I sure am gettin’ sick of eatin' baloney.
kw
You know what they say about baloney, don't you? Makes you horny.
What's that mean?
Are you so ignorant you don't know what horny means?
No, What's it mean? Laughing loudly, he pays for the baloney and goes out the door. Loretta follows, imploring.
Come on, Doo -= what's it mean?
(laughing) Just fix me a baioney sandwich, will ya, baby? Through the screen door we watch them get into the car an drive off. The radio behind the counter is still playing:

Here's a brand-new record by a brand new artist that's startin' to catch on with all you country music fans -- Loretta Lynn singin’ "Honky-Tonk Girl", The fat woman listens, idly beating time as she reads her newspaper.
The car whips down another highway; radio skips over the again, more music of the era. The highway seems empty and endless....
Long pan down it as "Honky Tonk Girl" plays. The car pull into the parking lot and Loretta gets out in her cowgirl outfit, looking eager. Doo stays in the car, sleepily tur on the radio.  kw 98
A kindly Dd named Hugh Cherry interviews Loretta.
With all these months of bein' on the road, have you hit Nashville yet?
No, sir, but I'm a-dyin' to. I'm gonna get on the Grand Ole Opry,’. too, soon as I can.
Well, sometimes you have to pay a lotta dues to get on the Opry.
Pay dues?
For most people it takes years and years of hard work. Still, from the looks of thing -- {reaches for a copy of Cash Box) -- you're off to a real good start ---
(oblivious) You reckon? Shoot, we been drivin’ so much I don't even know where I am half the time -- oh, it's fun, we just talk and sing and Doo, that's my husband, he'll.get to actin' horny ---
Doo's head jerks up.
(startled) What -- ?
(oblivious) And the more I laugh the hornier he gets --- The station goes dead. Doo slides down in the seat.
An irate Station Manager storms around at Loretta as Doo and Hugh Cherry look on. fanmreinn  kw 99
I don't know where you think you are, lady, but that kind of smut don't go in this part of the country.
I didn't know it was dirty: I thought horny just meant cuttin’ up and actin' sillv --
Come off the dumb hillbilly act, lady.
Mister, if you knew Loretta, you'd know that ain't no act.
(staunchily) Thank you, Doo.
I'll be damned lucky if the FCC don't lift my license for this. I can you one thing: I'll never play any record of yours on this station! He slams out. Loretta is miserable.
Dad-dammit, Loretta -- don't you ever stop to think what you're sayin?
You told me not to! And stop a-growlin' at me?
Don't worry about him, Kids. If you're on the charts, you'll get played all right. ©
What charts?
You got a hit -~ don't you know that? (sees their confusion) That really isn't an act, is it?
HUGH (Cont'd) Look here -- Cash Box magazine came out today, “Honky-Tonk Girl" by Loretta Lynn. You really didn't know? You're number fourteen, nationwide.

(embarrassed) Hell, mister, we're new at this.... He looks at Loretta; she looks at him, then both burst ou laughing and hugging each other. The Station Manager glow suspiciously through the window....

Doo drives along at a rapid clip, a little smile keeps pl around his lips, he hums along with a staticky song on th radio. We assume Loretta is asleep in the backseat. Then head appears behind Doo's. She begins to nuzzle him, run hands through his hair, onto his chest. Doo gets more and more distracted.
I love you, Doo.... His eyes cut back and forth, desperately searching for an

The car is parked in the shadows. The rest area is desert semi's whine down the interstate nearby. After a moment, gets out of the backseat, looking very contented. Loretta sits up, they look at each other. Smile. Doo drives on as she lies down to sleep.

She is asleep. Silence. She stirs, awakens. Looks in the front seat -- no Doolittle. A little alarmed, she sits up Looks out the window and discovers they are parked on a c street. She looks around and sees something that makes her gasp ---  al #02119 65

fhe ancient crumbling Ryman Auditorium. In the rising sun it seems infused with a golden glow...She gets out of the car. The streets are deserted, quiet. She stands in the middle of the street gazing at the old building in awe. Doo comes around the corner with a bag of coffee and doug nuts. Seeing her awestruck expression, he grins.
That o1' buildin’ would sure hold a lotta hay, wouldn't it?
That's the Grand Ole Opry, Doo!
You want chocolate or glazed?
The Grand Ole Opry... (suddenly frightened) Doo. What if they won't let me in there?
They better let us in. I just spent our last livin' cent on these dough- nuts. (pause) Besides, how they gonna keep us out? We're number fourteen. (beat) Nationwide.
A huge crowd roars, whoops, whistles; Grand Ole Opry Satu Night. On stage, an announcer, Grant Turner, introduces:
And now, the Grand Ole Opry presents the Pet Milk Show, with Ernest Tubb and his Texas Troubadours!
The crowd goes wild as Ernest sings "Walkin' the Floor Ov
Dozens of people milling around, spilling onstage as the goes on -- friends, relatives, hangers-on, sidemen, and s

head_text.subj: HANK SNOW, ROY ACUFF, MINNIE PEARL, BILL MONROE, LESTER

text: FLATT, etc. In the midst of this glamour are Doo, hiding his nervousn and Loretta in her homemade dress, looking lost and terri A nervous little Stage Manager {who stutters) is calling etta's name repeatedly, but it can't be heard over the di Finally she hears it -- her head jerks up in fright -- an she hurries nervously to the little man.

You Loretta Lynn? I been a-callin' and a-callin' and -- now Mr. Devine said to put you on Ernest's show; now you you go stand right yonder and keep your eyes on Ernest, and he'll introduce you. If the show ain't runnin" too long. He moves off quickly to find somebody else. Loretta, flus goes to the wings and waits, very frightened, uncertain.
What's the matter?
I'm scared, Doo -- scared I don't belong here. :
You belong here as much as anybody -- stop complainin' and relax.
Nine months ago I hadn't never sung for nobody ‘cept you and the kids -- I ain't ready, Doo. I ain't paid my dues to be here!
Then by God, we'll pay ‘em later on. He starts off.
Where you goin' -~ !
If there's one thing I can't stand, it's a nervous damn woman, I'm gonna get me some air. She's left alone, terrified. Looks out at Ernest Tubb, ho he'll never call her.
Doo comes out the stage door and lights a cigarette -- hi hands are shaking wildly. In front of him is the rear ent to Tootsie's Orchid Lounge -- he sees some musicians comi of it. He hurries inside,
Packed with musicians and singers. Pushing up to the bar, jostles against a sexy redhead who smiles at him drunkenl
What's your hurry, cowboy?
I'm tryin' to get me a quick beer and get back to the Opry ---
Well, you can't be shy -- Hey, Tootsie! Wait on this cowboy -- he's ina hurry!
Onstage, Ernest Tubb finishes a number.

Thank you, neighbors. Folks, right now I want y'all to meet a little gal I think you're gonna like a whole lot -- let's make her feel real welcome now... Miss Loretta Lynn! Applause: Tubb turns to her: she freezes. Grant Turner gi her a little shove and she's onstage and singing, growing and more relaxed and confident as the audience responds.  al 109 110
Doo still hasn't got his beer, and the Redhead is getting friendler. Behind the bar a radio is tuned to the Opry bu it can barely be heard above the noise.
Well, if you ain't a picker, what are you?
My wife's singin' on the Opry. I better forget about that drink ---
Oh, I see -= you're one of the husbands. Well, I'm one of the wives, darlin'. How 'bout one fifth wheel buyin' another one a drink?
(suddenly hears radio) That's her -- she's on right now! Goddammit!
Doo starts back, knows he'll never get there in time; lea over bar and tries to hear the radio. A large man -- Cowb comes by and puts his arm around Redhead.
H'o, sweet thang -- where's that big ugly husband of yours? .
Out in the parkin' lot tryin' to get sober enough to do his show.
(as they laugh loudly) Hey, y'all -- I'm tryin' to hear the radio ---
He's got a wife singin' on the Opry.
That right? Hell, you got it made, man. Just lay back and count it as the ol' lady rakes it in.
al
on
{getting mad) I do my share of the work, mister.
Sure you do, hoss.
I told you politely. I'm tryin' to hear the radio.

That's your job, huh? She sings and you listen. Doo whirls and socks Cowboy across the room. In the sudde quiet, Doo hears Loretta finishing her song -- just as Co recovers and leaps on Doo with a smash to the jaw. INT. OPRY STAGE - NIGHT lll Loretta blinks happily as the applause continues.
Miss Loretta Lynn, neighbors -- Loretta, how'd you like to come back and see us again next week?
Next week...? We-l...shoot, Mr. Tubb. I sure ain't got nothin’ else a-goin? g' Audience laughs and applauds; Ernest does his closing the

People throng around her, congratulating her, as she look around desperately for Doo. Finally, she spots him at the stage door hastling with the police guard who won't let h back it. She runs for him ---
She comes flying out the door and into his arms -- not no ing his jaw beginning to swell.
Did you hear ‘em, honey? Did you hear ‘em? They liked me!
kt o~ 113
I heard ‘em baby ---
They asked me to come back next week! It's like a dream, Doo!
What we gotta do now is set down and plan real careful what to do next.

I'm too happy to even think about that now! I don't care if I die = right now, Doo -~ if I never sing another song -- it just ain't never gonna get no better than this! (sees his jaw) You hurt yourself, honey? Your jaw's swellin' up ---
Just from grinnin', baby. Just from pure happiness.
Loretta's voice on loudspeakers to dozens of fans cluster around the record shop door. Fans passing in cars blow th horns and shout, etc. She sings, "I Fall to Pieces."
Live radio broadcast ("Midnight Jamboree"); fans jammed i among record shelves, etc. After the first verse of "I Fa to Pieces" Loretta says:

Friends, this song is the number: one hit by Patsy Cline, and I want to dedicate it to her, cause I guess y'all heard she's over here in the hospital ‘cause she was in a car wreck. Patsy, if you're listenin’ this song is for you. . Sings the last verse. In the audience is Doolittle, two children asleep in his arms, the other two drowsily hangi onto him. He listens, pleased, as she sings.  kt 116

Show’s over: Loretta and Ernest Tubb sign autographs. Doo pulls the car up and double-parks. The kids are sleeping. shiny new Cadillac suddenly double-parks in front of him aman jumps out. Doo sees him go up to Loretta, take her a and pull her aside, whispering in her ear. Doo growls, th open the door and heads for the man.
(excitedly) Doo -- listen here to this: Patsy Cline heard me sing her song tonight! She's a-wantin' to meet me -- right now!
(offers hand to Doo who is still suspicious) I'm Charlie Dick. Patsy's husband.
Boy, I'd give near anything to meet Patsy Cline -- _ (pleading look at Doo) But I reckon we gotta get them young ‘uns home....?

(beat) I'll get the kids home. If Patsy Cline wants to meet you, then you go on and meet her. You can't pass up somethin' like this. She happily kisses Doo and gets in Charlie's car and they drive away. Doo gets in his car and takes the kids home.

Charlie, with something tucked under his coat, leads Lore down the corridor toward a room. From the room comes loud laughter -- and two nurses come out laughing and shaking heads as they pass Loretta. Loretta, excited and thrilled any fan, goes tentatively into ---
Loretta draws back, shocked; in bed is a woman with her f bruised and bandaged, her eyes black -- Patsy Cline.
“~~ kt
Charlie -- you get me beer like I told you?
Right here, Patsy. Pulls a six pack from under his coat; opens one. Patsy gr for a hospital straw on her bedside table.

(to Loretta) Hand me that straw, willya, honey? Loretta does and Patsy puts in the can and drinks the bee Charlie kisses Patsy lightly winks at Loretta and exits. Loretta stands staring, speechless, at Patsy drinking the beer through the straw.
(after a moment) What's the matter? Ain't you never seen no glamourous star before? (beat) Want a beer?
(shakes her head) Are...are you really Patsy Cline....?
Are you really Loretta Lynn? (Loretta smiles, relaxes a little) You're stirrin' things up around this town, you know that? How many times you sung on the Opry now?
(proudly) I been on seventeen straight times.
Lotta gals been here a lot longer'n you ain't gettin’ on near that much. (beat) They're askin' who you been sleepin’ with to get on so much.
(shocked) I ain’t sleepin' with nobody to get nothin’ -- that's the dirtiest doggone lie -- who's a-sayin' that?
o~ kt
(smiles) Gals that are sleepin' with everybody and still ain't gettin’ nowhere. Whoo -- you got a temper big as your voice, ain't you? That's good -- they both come in handy in this business.

(suddenly) I just can't believe I'm a-standin' here talkin' to Patsy Cline! Oh, Patsy, sO many good things are a- happenin' so fast to me and Doolittle -- he's my husband only most people calls him Mooney -- and now, meetin' you -- Patsy, you ain't mad at me for doin' your song tonight, are you?

(softly) Mad? If anything, I'm scared -- you done it so good, I... (stops; has tears in her eyes) Well. Most people wouldn't've thought of singin' to me like that. {wipes her eyes) Listen: when I get outta here me and you gonna go out together and raise some hell -~ okay? Us country gals orta stick together.

fully recovered -- very glamourous, smiling, very much a sweeps on stage to loud applause and sings "Back in’Baby' Arms." In the wings, Loretta stands watching, unconsciously imit Patsy's movenents. Patsy turns and smiles at her, Loretta smiles back happily. Song continues.

Noisy, smoky, crowded with musicians and singers. Patsy bursts in the backdoor with Loretta, waves at acquaintanc and heads for a booth where Charlie and Doolittle are dri pouring bourbon into "set-ups" under the table.
mw 118
What've y'all two devils been doin' besides gettin' in trouble -- don't tell me. Hey, Tootsie -- bring us two co-colas!
Hey, Patsy, Mooney says he's gonna take me squirrel huntin'.
(trying Charlie's drink) Don't you bring home no squirrels, Charlie Dick. When I left Virginia I swore I'd never eat another damn squirrel long as I lived.
Boy, I love squirrel meat. Don't you like squirrels, Patsy?
Reckon I must. I married Charlie. Charlie laughs loudly; Patsy hugs him affectionately.
Charlie knows I love him -- but I have to remind him ever now and then he ain't nothin’ but a damn tax deduction.
(picking it up) Yeah, Doolittle Lynn, that goes for you, too. And don't you forget it! Doo doesn't laugh. His eyes narrow.

small, modest house. Doo on phone setting up an appointme for Loretta; she making sandwiches for the kids. Through window she sees Patsy's Cadillac roar into the driveway. gets out waving and bursts into the house.
Little gal -- you and Mooney are comin' on the road with me. How soon can you get ready?
mw
The road...?
We can't do it, Patsy. We got meetin's, record dates ~~~
They'll be here when you get back. You can't be a country singer without you go on the road -~ now you gotta go, it's all set.
We could get my brother to set with the kids -- aw, Doo, can't we go?
Is Charlie goin'?
Charlie don't like the road. Besides, he's got a day job.

Doggone it, I'm a-goin'. How about it, Doo. You comin', too? He looks at her levelly, then nods. Patsy throws her arms around Loretta. Doo goes into the kitchen where the kids eating, watching curiously.
An old model bus speeds down the highway. Int. BUS - DAY 120 Patsy and Lorraine ride together, looking at sights along way, laughing. Doo stares out the window nearby. Patsy's band is also aboard.
The bus pulis in behind it.
The place is packed as Patsy finishes "Walkin' After Midn
Doo and Loretta are in the crowd near the stage. Deo is drinking. Slick Cowboy Number Two comes up to Loretta.
Hey, honey, how ‘bout dancin" one?
(motions to Doo) Ask my husband. Slick moves off.
If you don't get me a weddin' ring soon I swear I'm gonna buy my own self one.
I'll get you a weddin' ring, don't worry.
When? Our Golden Weddin' day? Patsy is introducing her (ad lib) and she goes on stage.

This here's a song I wrote about my husband. That's him standin' right over there, boys, with that mean, jealous look. She sings "Don't Come Home A-Drinkin" (With Lovin' On You Mind.) Doo at bar orders drink from the Bartender.

That's your wife up yonder, ain't it? (Doo nods) She makes it and you spend it, huh? Boy, you got it made. Doo tenses, considers bashing his face in; doesn't. Turns back and watches Loretta, growling, drinking.
Doo's asleep. Loretta is a few seats away, a flashlight propped as she writes a song. Patsy wanders up, Loretta s
Don't stop -- I'm just wanderin', can't sleep....
It wasn't comin', anyway.
A new song? That's a gift. I wish I had, bein' able to write. How do you do it?
I just watch to see what me and Doolittle is gonna do, and write it down.
{shows a piece of paper) Here's a new one they sent me. See what you think.
Patsy sings a few bars of "Sweet Dreams of You."
Mm. That's pretty.
Ain't it? First time I heard it I thought I was gonna cream my jeans.
What's that mean? Patsy looks at her, then leans over and whispers in her Loretta looks surprised.
Aw, women can't do that. (beat) Can they?
ear. The bus is pulling in behind the outdoor stage where a cr is running sound checks. 122 123 and 124 125  mw 126 127
A curtain strung over the bus' backseats makes a dressing room. Mirrors propped on seats, etc. Patsy and Loretta ar dressing. Sounds of show in b.g.
Don't you ever wear no makeup?
Doo don't like it. He likes me natural.
Ain't nothin' more natural than” Makeup. Here. Tosses Loretta some lipstick, eye liner, powder which Lor happily puts on with the air of doing something forbidden
(getting up) I'm gonna bring you on right after my first song, so be ready. Loretta nods; Patsy goes. Loretta continues making up.
deserted except for Doo, slumped in a seat, sipping from bottle. Patsy heard singing in the b.g. Loretta comes out the back heading for the door, Seeing Doo, she is startle
You scared me. What're you doin' sittin' there like that?
(peers at her) What you got on your face...?
I just thought I'd try it -- you like it?
You know I don't like it -- get it off.
No.
I said get it off ---
He lurches out of his seat for her but she quickly runs o the bus toward the stage. Doo stands glowering angrily in dark.
Loretta enters to applause and she and Patsy begin "Sweet Dreams of You."

Intercut with above. As the girls sing in close harmony Doo wanders, resentful drinking. Near the stage a few cars are pulled up, includ a late model convertible with an attractive blonde sittin on the fender, watching the show. Doo looks interestedly her; she returns it....

Show is over; crowds gone. Bus is running and loaded. Pat and Loretta walk toward it from the stage -- they've been signing autographs. Loretta suddenly sees the convertible with Doo and the Blonde kissing inside. The blonde is wea Doo's hat. Loretta's throat catches; her eyes blaze. She stalks furiously toward the car. The blonde looks up startled:
Woman, if you wanna keep that arm you better get it offa my husband ---
(defiantly) Who you tellin' what?
I'm just about to stop tellin' and start hittin' ---

Well, let me tell you somethin! -- if you was keepin' your man satis- fied he wouldn't have to go nowhere else! Loretta starts for her; but the Woman quickly back~pedals around the car. The bus horn honks in the b.g.
(to Woman) I ain't got time to fool with you now. (to Doolittle) You come on, if you can walk -- they gonna leave without us.
{they hurry for the bus) I can walk all right. What're you gettin’ in such an uproar about? I wasn't doin' nothin' anyway.
Yeah, I saw you doin' nothin’ ---
I got tired of standin' around by myself -- I need somebody to talk to ---
That didn't look like no talkin’ to me --- She gets on the bus; he follows.
The others watch as they continue the fight.
I'm warning you ~- I better not ever catch you with trash like that again ---
Don't you warn me about nothin', woman -- you hear me? Not about nothin'! They realize everybody is watching them. They sit in separate seats, still furious. Patsy looks concerned. The bus pulls out.
Doo slumps, glowering, hung over. Loretta is angry too, scribbling furiously on a piece of paper. The rest of the bus watches them as if they were about to explode.

(after a moment) Doo? Listen here to this. (reads from paper) ‘Women like you are a dime a dozen you can find 'em anywhere. For you to move in I'd have to move over and I'm gonna stay right here. It'll be over my dead body so get out while you can. ‘Cause you ain't woman enough to take my man.‘ The others watch tensely as Doo growls, raises his bloods eyes.
Where'n the hell you get the idea for them things, I'll never know. Loretta looks at him incredulously -- he grins. Then. she grins. He puts his arm around her as the others look on i amazement.
Owen Bradley supervises a large professional recording se of "You Ain't Woman Enough." Doo and the kids watch proud from the booth.
